Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the Undergraduate Knot Theory Conference 2019, held at the University of Washington Bothell on July 19-21, 2019. Knot theory is a field very amenable to research by undergraduates; a variety of REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) programs in mathematics have a knot theory component. Moreover, many faculty members would like to involve students in undergraduate research in knot theory. This conference will bring together experts in knot theory with undergraduates who are either currently participating in knot theory REUs, undergraduates who have participated in knot theory research, current graduate students who participated as undergraduates in knot theory research, and perhaps most importantly, faculty who either have involved undergraduates in knot theory research or who would like to involve undergraduates.

This conference provides an opportunity for students to experience a mathematics research conference specifically designed for and directed toward them. As a centerpiece, the conference features a collective problem session to give participants numerous ideas for future research directions. Moreover, the conference will establish a supportive network of students and faculty with an interest in knot theory research, thus furthering the involvement of students in the field of mathematics.

The conference URL is https://sites.google.com/view/unknot-iv/home

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major goal of the project was to create a community of students and faculty with the common goal of engaging in research in knot theory. In order to achieve this goal, the UnKnot IV conference was hosted July 19-21, 2019 at the University of Washington Bothell. It brought together 45 undergraduates who are either interested in knot theory or who have already done research in knot theory, 5 graduate students who did undergraduate research themselves or who would like to get involved in collaborative research with undergraduates, and 28 faculty members who have an interest in working with undergraduates on research related to knot theory. This unique conference structure allowed for vertical integration from undergraduate students to undergraduate faculty to graduate students to experts in the field. The focus of this conference was on research that has been done by undergraduates and on open problems amenable to research by undergraduates. Many opportunities for research projects were presented.

This conference provided a venue for participants (undergraduates, graduate students, and faculty alike) to share their previous work and get new ideas for future research related to knot theory and its applications. In addition to presentations, there were other community building events for all participants. One of our keynote speakers led a Rope Magic Workshop which included fun hands-on activities. Another keynote speaker wrote and organized skits for a Mathematical Dinner Theatre which included opportunities for participants to serve as actors in the skits. An open problem session was held as the closing event of the conference. During this time period, Colin Adams led the group in generating open questions based on the topics presented at the conference. This list was shared with all participants and will serve as a resource for those mentoring undergraduate research in knot theory.

This conference has the potential to have a dramatic impact on the future of topology that could reverberate for a long time to come. In past years, the conference has sparked new collaborations amongst participants and has led to new avenues of knot theory research. We expect similar outcomes from the 2019 conference. Having a network of other students and faculty with a common interest provides support for future endeavors. Indeed, one of the outcomes for this conference was providing a venue to reunite past knot theory conference and workshop participants in order to nurture a small community of researchers that are very enthusiastic about mentoring undergraduate research in knot theory.
